summary:
<|user|>
This research focuses on exploring the specific psychological factors, including personality traits, defense mechanisms, central sensitization, and childhood traumatic experiences, that characterize and differentiate individuals with chronic migraine, fibromyalgia, and vulvodynia from healthy controls. The study involves a psychosocial cluster analysis using a protocol of self-report questionnaires consisting of two parts: the main and the optional one. Primary and secondary outcome measures include the Central Sensitivity Index, Traumatic Experiences Index, PID-5 Short form, Defense Mechanism Rating Scales - DMRS-SR-30, Highly Sensitive Person Scale, Mental Pain Questionnaire, Environmental Sensitivity, Brief Symptom Inventory, SF-12 - Quality of Life Assessment, Toronto Alexithymia Scale, SPQ - Social Support Questionnaire, Short Form McGill Questionnaire - Adapted for genito-pelvic pain, and Female Sexual Function Index. The study aims to contribute to the understanding of the specific psychological factors that play a role in the genesis and maintenance of these conditions, with the ultimate goal of identifying areas of greatest interest for clinical intervention tailored to the person.

<|assistant|>
This clinical trial, titled "Comparison of the Pressure Ulcer Prevention Effects of Two Mattresses With Different Support Surfaces Used in Bedridden Patients," aims to prevent pressure sores in bedridden patients by comparing the effectiveness of two mattresses with different support surfaces. Patients with a low risk of pressure sores according to the Braden Scale, up to 4 weeks of hospitalization, and a BMI less than 30 are eligible. Group I receives a massage mattress with a cube/block system and vibration, while Group II receives a viscoelastic mattress with an orthopedic support surface, both routinely used in the unit. Both groups are assessed initially using the Braden Scale and undergo daily pressure ulcer assessments for four weeks. The primary outcome measure is the number of patients without pressure ulcers, which will be calculated for each group in square centimeters using a wound measurement ruler. The study design is randomized, parallel assignment, triple masking.

Can you please summarize the benefits of exercise for children with type 1 diabetes and why traditional exercises may not be preferred by them?

<|assistant|>
This clinical trial, titled "The Effect of Virtual Reality on Preoperative Anxiety Before Abdominal Surgery," aims to analyze the impact of virtual reality on anxiety management before abdominal surgery. The study intends to answer two questions: what is the frequency of anxiety before abdominal surgery, and what is the effect of virtual reality on anxiety management during the preoperative period? The trial includes three groups: an experimental group (Virtual Reality Glasses Group), a placebo comparator group (Non-Virtual Reality Glasses Group), and a control group (No Intervention: Control Group). The participants in the experimental and placebo comparator groups will watch a video, one with virtual reality glasses (Behavioral: Watching video with virtual glasses) and the other with a plain version without the glasses (Behavioral: watching video without virtual glasses), respectively. The smart bracelet will record the stress levels, and necessary variables will be recorded with the data collection form. Preoperative anxiety levels will be measured using the Visual Anxiety Scale (VAS-A) and the smart bracelet, both before and after the video application. The inclusion criteria are individuals aged 18 or over, who can communicate in Turkish, volunteer to participate in the study, have abdominal surgery, and do not have any obstacles to communication. Exclusion criteria include failing to communicate, being in isolation, having a surgical intervention other than abdominal surgery, having a health problem preventing virtual glass use, having a vision problem, or applying premedication. With this experimental research method (parallel assignment, intervention, and control groups), the study aims to determine the effect of virtual reality on preoperative anxiety before abdominal surgery. The outcomes measured include stress levels measured by the smart bracelet and the VAS-A scale for both preoperative anxiety levels before and after watching the video. The statistical methods to be used include the Kolmogorov-Smirnov test, Single Sample t-Test, One- and Multi-Way Analysis of Variance, Spearman's Correlation Analysis, Pearson's Correlation Analysis, and Mann-Whitney U Test, depending on the normality of the data distribution. A total of 96 patients, with 32 patients in each group, are expected to participate in the study.

<|assistant|>
The clinical trial, titled "Clinical Performance and Safety of Suture-TOOL for Abdominal Wound Closure in Men and Women Patients Undergoing Elective Open Abdominal Surgery," aims to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of a new suture device, Suture-TOOL, for closing abdominal wounds in patients undergoing elective open abdominal surgery. The study is a single-arm prospective interventional study, with patients receiving Suture-TOOL for abdominal closure. The primary outcome measure is the proportion of patients with a Suture length/Wound length (SL/WL) ratio of 4 or higher. Secondary outcome measures include the number of stitches used, the number of sutures used, closure time, surgeons' comfort with the device, and surgeons' satisfaction with the closure result. Exclusion criteria include previous midline abdominal surgery, physical or pre-operative findings that may interfere with the study, allergy to drugs or allergic reactions, disseminated cancer disease, collagen diseases, immune deficiency disorders, life expectancy less than 1 year, medications that could interfere with the study, hormonal contraceptives for women, pregnancy or breastfeeding, and vulnerable subjects who cannot fully understand the study. The study measures the SL/WL-ratio, stitch count, numbers of sutures used, closure time, surgeons' comfort with the device, and surgeons' satisfaction with the closure result.

<|assistant|>
The "Immune Biomarker Study for Salivary Gland Carcinoma" aims to investigate the immune response in patients with salivary gland cancer. The study includes an observational group with newly diagnosed cancer patients, a control group with patients with benign salivary gland tumors, and a healthy control group. The primary outcome measures include changes in an immune matrix, longitudinal immunophenotyping, and analysis of cytokines and metabolites. The study also involves the analysis of the patient's microbiome. Participants in all groups will have samples collected from their tumors (for cancer patients), benign tumors (for the control group), or resected tissue during functional surgery (for the healthy control group). The study will follow the participants for up to 5 years, with analysis at several points in the treatment course. No healthy volunteers are being recruited for this study. Key inclusion criteria include a diagnosis of salivary gland cancer, benign salivary gland tumors, or functional diseases of the nose or ear, as well as the ability to provide informed consent and collect samples. Exclusion criteria include distant metastasis, prior cancer in the past 5 years, and inability to provide informed consent or follow study procedures.

<|assistant|>
The clinical trial titled "Determination of Compliance to Mediterranean Diet, Impacts on Walking and Quality of Life in Multiple Sclerosis" aims to investigate the adherence to the Mediterranean diet, the usage of various nutritional supplements, physical activity habits, walking-related problems, and quality of life in individuals with Multiple Sclerosis (MS). This study will measure compliance to the Mediterranean diet using the 14-item Mediterranean Diet Adaptation Scale (PREDIMED) with a cutoff score of ≤5 (low agreement), 6-9 (moderate agreement), and ≥10 (high agreement). The study will assess the quality of life using the Multiple Sclerosis International Quality of Life Scale, which ranges from 0-124 points, and the impacts on walking utilizing the 12-item MS Gait Scale, with lower scores indicating better gait impairment. Additionally, the study will determine the disability status of the patients using the Expanded Disability Status Scale (EDSS), which measures disability and neurological symptoms in MS patients, with a score ranging from 0 (no disability or disorder) to 10 (MS-related death). The study focuses on individuals aged 18-65 with a confirmed MS diagnosis, excluding pregnant or postpartum individuals, individuals with an active infection, individuals with another disease that prevents physical activity, and individuals with a disease that requires a special diet.

<|assistant|>
The SIIT-CD Study is a randomized, controlled trial investigating the efficacy and safety of a selective intensive induction therapy based on ustekinumab clinical decision-making tools in patients with Crohn's disease. Participants must have a diagnosis of CD with active disease, be between the ages of 18 and 75, and have moderate and low responsive activity as determined by UST-CDST scores. The experimental group receives two intravenous doses of ustekinumab at weeks 0 and 8, followed by either intravenous or standard subcutaneous injection according to CRP standards at week 12. The control group receives standard induction therapy without ustekinumab. The primary outcome measure is the difference in clinical response rate at week 24 between the intensive and standard induction regimens. Exclusion criteria include significant liver, kidney, endocrine, respiratory, neurological, or cardiovascular diseases, extensive or total colectomy, current or previous ileostomy or colostomy, fibrous stenosis or prestenotic dilatation, or contraindications to ustekinumab. It is an open-label study with paralleled assignment and a primary purpose of treatment.

<|assistant|>
This clinical trial, titled "The Preference of a Culturally and Linguistically Diverse (CALD) Population for Second Line OAB Therapy: a Discrete Choice Experiment," examines the preferences of adults with overactive bladder (OAB) from diverse backgrounds for second line therapies, specifically Botox and sacral neuromodulation (SNM). Participants, who meet the inclusion criteria of OAB and do not have a history of SNM or Botox, will fill out a questionnaire comparing two fictional therapy options with different Botox and SNM characteristics. This study measures participant preferences through a discrete choice questionnaire with a duration of one hour.

Can you provide a list of the secondary outcomes measures being used in the study?

The clinical trial, titled "Fractionated Stereotactic Ablative Body Radiotherapy (SBRT) With FOcal Dose Escalation on Dominant Lesion in Localized Prostate Cancer," aims to treat intermediate or high-risk localized prostate cancer using SBRT with a focal boost on the dominant lesion identified by mpMRI. Eligible participants have confirmed adenocarcinoma of the prostate, intermediate or high-risk disease, visible dominant lesion (DIL) on mpMRI, clinical stage T2-T3a, urinary function preserved (if prostate volume > 80 cc), and ECOG 0-1. The primary endpoint is biochemical progression-free survival (PSA nadir + 2 ng/ml) at 3 years, and secondary endpoints include acute and late urinary and rectal treatment-related adverse events, as well as patient-reported outcomes and quality of life assessments. The study adopts a single group intervention model with SBRT delivering 36.25 Gy to the entire prostate in 5 fractions, followed by a DIL focal boost up to 50 Gy in 5 sessions with partial protection of the prostatic urethra and bladder trigone. Daily IGRT with cone beam CT and gold-seed fiducial tracking are also part of the intervention. Acute and late urinary and rectal treatment-related adverse events are graded according to CTCAE v5.0 scale, and QoL is assessed using the EPIC-26 short form.

<|assistant|>
The clinical trial study, titled "Serious Games as Emerging E-health Interventions for Young People with Neurological or Respiratory Disorders (SMILER)- Project@Cnr," aims to evaluate the effectiveness of serious games (SG) as a support tool for the asthma treatment plan in adolescents between the ages of 12 and 17 with controlled asthma. The study will recruit two groups of participants with group 1 receiving the SG intervention and group 2 following the standard treatment plan. The primary outcome measures will be assessed via questionnaires, specifically the Pediatric Quality of Life Inventory (PedsQL) and Skills and Difficulties Quantification (SDQ-Ita), at 6 months. Secondary outcome measures, including the Conserved Transcriptional Response to Adversity (CTRA), will also be evaluated at 6 months. Group 1's SG will utilize a running game with adaptive tools based on real motor and physiological data acquired during each session to ensure the child's movements are within the aerobic zone. The study excludes individuals with recent asthma flare-ups, certain respiratory infections or diseases, and pregnant women.

The clinical trial, titled "Efficacy and Safety Study of Frexalimab (SAR441344) in Adults With Nonrelapsing Secondary Progressive Multiple Sclerosis," is a Phase 3 study comparing the efficacy and safety of Frexalimab (a drug for multiple sclerosis) to a placebo in individuals with nonrelapsing secondary progressive MS. The trial includes participants aged 18-60 years who have progressive MS symptoms with evidence of disability progression within the past 12 months. The primary endpoint is the time to onset of composite confirmed disability progression over 6 months. Secondary endpoints include shorter progression times, cognitive function, brain volume loss, and safety assessments. The study design is randomized, double-blind, and quadruple-masked, with participants receiving either Frexalimab or a matching placebo via IV infusion. MRI contrast-enhancing agents are administered to both groups according to their respective labels. Safety assessments include adverse events, serious adverse events, permanent discontinuation of study intervention due to an adverse event, potentially clinically significant abnormalities, and antibody and Ig level changes over time. Plasma neurofilament light chain levels and Frexalimab plasma concentration are also evaluated over time. The study enrollment and follow-up period span 204 weeks.

<|assistant|>
This clinical trial aims to compare the effectiveness of the Mishra and modified Millard techniques in repairing unilateral cleft lips in infants aged 2-6 months. The study is randomized and open label, with three arms: a control group receiving standard cleft lip repair, and two treatment groups with either the Mishra or modified Millard techniques applied. The primary outcome measure is the anthropometric measurements of lip height, length, and philtral length at 3 months post-surgery. The trial will investigate the efficacy of the Mishra and modified Millard techniques in addressing the unique challenges resulting from cleft lip, such as lip notching, vertical scar contracture, and distortion of the Cupid's bow. The study builds upon existing research in the field and emphasizes the importance of anthropometric evaluation and comparison to assess surgical outcomes.

This clinical trial, titled "Multidisciplinary Approach for High Risk Patients Leading to Early Diagnosis of Canadians in Heart Failure", aims to improve the screening and early diagnosis of heart failure in individuals at high risk, such as those with a history of coronary artery disease, diabetes, atrial fibrillation, stroke, peripheral artery disease, chronic kidney disease, regular loop diuretic use, or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Eligible participants, aged 40 or older, will be recruited through extracted primary care electronic health records with an inclusion and exclusion criteria. A randomized un-blinded study will compare two arms: one with an intervention group, including an NT-proBNP test, an artificial intelligence (AI) echocardiogram, and a heart failure (HF) focused examination, and another with routine care. The study will measure the incidence of HF diagnosis, HF events, urgent HF visits, and HF hospitalizations over a six-month period. The trial will also assess the incidence of prescription for guideline recommended HF therapies in patients diagnosed with HFrEF and the number of HF events in this population. Keywords for this study include heart failure screening, natriuretic peptides, and artificial intelligence echocardiography.

<|assistant|>
The clinical trial aims to evaluate the most appropriate weight-based scalar for propofol dosing during anesthesia induction by comparing the dose given according to total body weight, ideal body weight, and lean body weight in patients with a BMI below 35. The study includes patients over 18 undergoing general anesthesia for 2-6 hours, excluding those with propofol allergy or contraindication. Tanita analysis will be performed to calculate the body weight, ideal body weight, and lean body weight of participants. Propofol infusion will be started according to total body weight and stopped with a BIS value between 50 and 40. The relationship between propofol dosage and body mass index will be evaluated. This is an observational study with routine anesthesia procedures applied. The primary outcome measure is the ratio of propofol dose with sufficient anesthesia depth according to total and lean body weight, compared at two time points. Keywords related to the study include lean body weight and propofol intubation conditions.

<|assistant|>
This is a prospective cohort study to evaluate the effectiveness and tolerability of letermovir, an oral antiviral medication, for the prevention of cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection in individuals who have undergone heart or lung transplants and are at high risk of developing CMV-related complications. Eligible participants will receive either letermovir or standard valganciclovir prophylaxis, and outcomes such as CMV viral load, acute cellular rejection, neutropenia, severe thrombocytopenia, and unplanned discontinuation of immunosuppressant medications will be monitored throughout the one-year study period. The study aims to identify any potential benefits and drawbacks of using letermovir for CMV prophylaxis in this population.

<|assistant|>
This clinical trial, titled "Development and Validation of the PHYSIOSCORE," aims to create a tool called PHYSIOSCORE to assess the complexity level and physiotherapy care required for hospitalized patients with heart or lung conditions. The study involves two phases: Phase 1 involves developing the PHYSIOSCORE with a committee of specialist physical therapists, and Phase 2 includes establishing the concordance and interrater reliability of the scale by another group of ten physical therapists through a observational, single-center study of 110 patients. The study measures respiratory and neuromuscular variables in hospitalized patients, and Phase 3 will clinically validate the instrument by assessing the level of attention and complexity of physiotherapy care required for one professional and comparing it to the care provided by a second physical therapist with at least five years of experience. The study uses three scales to evaluate patients: EuroSCORE16, SAPS 317, and ARISCAT18, and evaluates patients at different points during hospitalization, including pre- and postoperative cardiac surgery, immediately postoperative, at ICU discharge, and seven days later or at hospital discharge, whichever occurs first.

<|assistant|>
The SAVAL trial, short for Selective Adjuvant Therapy for HPV-mediated Oropharynx SCCs Based on Residual Circulating Tumor DNA Levels, is a phase II single arm clinical study for patients with HPV or its surrogate marker p16-positive oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinomas (OPSCC). Eligible participants undergo transoral robotic surgery (TORS) and have positive ctDNA levels prior to the procedure. Patients with intermediate pathological features and negative ctDNA after TORS are observed without radiation, similar to standard of care, while those with high risk pathological features receive standard adjuvant therapy. Patients with low risk features continue standard of care observation. The study aims to evaluate progression-free survival in the experimental arm and secondary outcomes such as rate of recurrence, locoregional recurrence, overall survival, distant metastases, and treatment complications.

<|assistant|>
The study aims to investigate the feasibility and preliminary outcomes of a digital health coaching (DHC) intervention for patients with relapsed/refractory multiple myeloma (RRMM) through the collection of patient reported outcomes (PROs) and wearable data. Participants will receive a 3-month DHC program and a Fitbit device for activity tracking. The feasibility of the intervention will be measured by a retention rate of at least 70%, and secondary outcomes will include changes in self-efficacy in coping with specific aspects of cancer treatment and management, as measured by the Cancer Behavior Inventory-Brief Form (CBI-B). The study will provide insights into the symptom burden, health self-efficacy, and financial, physiologic, and psychosocial well-being of patients with RRMM through the integration of PROs, wearable data, and clinical information. The study is a single arm cohort design, and all participants will receive the DHC intervention with a Fitbit device.

This is a randomized clinical trial to assess the efficacy of a porcine acellular dermal matrix (PADM) in combination with a coronally advanced flap (CAF) for treating localized gingival recessions in adults aged 18 to 60 with recessions ranging from 3 to 5 mm and at least 2mm of keratinized tissue width. The study's primary outcome is the reduction of gingival recession height, measured at baseline, 6 months, and 12 months. The study also evaluates the thickness of keratinized tissue following periodontal plastic surgery. The CAF-only group serves as the active comparator. Patients with diabetes, smoking or pregnancy, plaque or gingival index >20%, or allergies to PADM components are excluded. The study is quadruple masked.

<|assistant|>
This clinical trial, titled "Effect of Physical Exercise Performed Through Virtual Reality Games on Chronic Renal Patients During Hemodialysis," aims to compare the changes in heart rate variability modulation between chronic renal patients who perform conventional physical exercise and those who engage in virtual environment exercises during hemodialysis sessions. The study will involve two groups: Group A, who will participate in 10 interventions of virtual reality exercises, and Group B, who will participate in 10 interventions of conventional physical exercise on a cycle ergometer. After a washout period, the groups will switch exercises. Heart rate, respiratory rate, oxygen saturation, blood pressure, laboratory tests, and questionnaires assessing quality of life, anxiety, and depression will be measured in all groups. The primary outcome measure is the heart rate variability behavior during interventions with virtual reality and stationary bike while in hemodialysis. Secondary outcome measures include blood pressure, heart rate, respiratory rate, and oxygen saturation during interventions. The study enrolls chronic renal patients with diagnosed chronic renal insufficiency requiring hemodialysis, aged over 18, and possessing medical clearance for participating in physical exercise. Exclusion criteria include use of medications affecting the cardiovascular system, persistent pain and fatigue affecting exercise, change in renal treatment during the application period, and absence from three consecutive exercise training sessions. The study has a longitudinal cross-over clinical trial design, with randomization and a crossover assignment. Masking is not utilized. Virtual reality exercises and conventional exercise on a cycle ergometer will be implemented for both experimental and active comparator groups.

This clinical trial titled "Study of the Effectiveness of Central Line Placement Using an Ultraportable Ultrasound Device" aims to compare the effectiveness of placing a central venous line using an ultraportable ultrasound device with the conventional method. The study involves patients aged 18 and above scheduled to have a central venous line inserted preoperatively or in the ICU. Participants undergo randomization to either the experimental arm, where a central venous line is placed using an ultraportable ultrasound device, or the sham comparator arm, where a conventional method is used. The primary outcome measure is the length of the procedure, which is measured in seconds from the beginning of the ultrasound scan to the fixation of the catheter to the skin. The study excludes pregnant women, patients with jugular thrombosis at the insertion site, and emergency procedures without informed consent. The study design is randomized with parallel assignment and single masking.

<|assistant|>
The clinical trial aimed to investigate the therapeutic efficacy of the Erbium:YAG laser in postpartum women with episiotomy scars in reducing genital pelvic pain and promoting scar tissue healing. The study was a randomized, sham-controlled trial that enrolled women who had given birth within the past six months with episiotomy, vulvar pain, and dyspareunia. The intervention group received three sessions of Er:YAG laser therapy using the Fotona Dynamis Er:YAG Laser System with the R11 and PS03 handpieces at intervals of 15-21 days. The experimental group received the standard Er:YAG laser treatment, while the sham group received a sham treatment with the same parameters but a sham handpiece. Both groups underwent evaluation of pain, scar tissue healing, and sexual function at six months post-intervention using the visual analogue scale, USG Elastography, and Female Sexual Function Index, respectively. The study also assessed the incidence and severity of device-related adverse events. The study's primary endpoint was the rate of change in pain, and secondary endpoints included the rate of improvement in sexual function and safety. The study keywords included episiotomy, complications, Er-YAG laser, vulvodynia, and vulva pain.

The clinical trial focuses on investigating the relationship between the gut microbiome and gallstone disease. The study aims to understand the profile of gut bacteria in 75 adults diagnosed with gallstone disease and its correlation with complications and patient outcomes. Participants will be asked to provide stool samples at various timepoints, including diagnosis, prior to surgery, immediately after surgery, and six months post-surgery. The study will collect clinical and demographic data, including anthropometry, blood test results, and imaging findings. The primary outcome measure is the bacterial DNA profile, assessing the diversity of species present in the stool of participants. The study aims to identify differences in the gut microbiome between patients who develop complications and those who do not, with the end goal of determining interventions to reduce the development of complications. The study enrolls adults aged 18 and above, including pregnant women, diagnosed with gallstone disease through confirmatory imaging. The study is a prospective cohort design with a maximum study completion of three years from cholecystectomy.

<|assistant|>
The study aims to investigate the association between a specific liver function test, known as the Aspartate Aminotransferase to Platelet (APR) ratio, and the development of sepsis-associated liver dysfunction (SALD) in adult sepsis patients. SALD is defined by either elevated ALT or AST levels of over 20 times the upper limit of normal, or TBIL levels of 2.0mg/dL or greater. The study excludes individuals with chronic liver diseases, viral hepatitis, and lengthy ICU stays, among other criteria. The design is a non-randomized observational study with two groups: those who did not develop SALD and those who did. Both groups receive standard antibiotic therapy, infection control, and organ support. The primary outcome is the occurrence of SALD within 30 days of ICU admission, while mortality at the same time point is a secondary outcome. The study utilizes the MIMIC IV database for association analysis, which is then validated with the authors' own data.

The study titled "Analyse Of Early Skın To Skın Contact's Impact Upon Maternal-Infant Bondıng And Perceptıon Of Traumatıc Bırth" aims to investigate the effects of early skin-to-skin contact on maternal-infant attachment and perception of traumatic birth. The study design is a randomized controlled experimental study, and the sample consisted of 350 women who had normal deliveries at the Training and Research Hospital in Batman between December 2021 and May 2022. The experimental group (n=180) received skin-to-skin contact immediately after birth for a minimum of 15 minutes. The control group (n=187) received standard midwifery practices and neonatal routine care procedures without skin-to-skin contact. Both groups completed questionnaires to measure maternal attachment and perception of traumatic birth at different time points after birth. The study measures maternal attachment using the adapted Turkish version of Mary E. Muller's attachment scale and traumatic birth perception using a scale developed by Yalnız et al. (2016). The study plans include collecting data from December 2021 to May 2022. The keywords provided by Centre Hospitalier Valida include traumatic birth, maternal attachment, skin-to-skin, and midwifery.

<|assistant|>
This clinical trial investigates the effectiveness of sacral erector spinae plane block (ESPB) in managing post-operative pain in patients undergoing lumbar discectomy surgery. The study is a randomized, controlled, double-blind trial with 54 patients allocated to either the ESPB group or a control group who received standard general anesthesia. Both groups received patient-controlled analgesia (PCA) and their pain levels were measured using Visual Analogue Scale (VAS) scores over 24 hours. Total consumption of analgesic and rescue analgesics were also recorded. The ESPB group received ESPB at the end of the surgery, while the control group did not receive any block. The study measures patient pain levels and total opioid consumption, as well as the incidence of side effects and patient satisfaction. The trial will help determine the usefulness of sacral ESPB in reducing post-operative pain in lumbar discectomy patients.

<|assistant|>
The study aims to develop and validate a non-invasive multimodal ultrasound-based imaging biomarker for myofascial pain, which is a contributing factor to chronic low back pain. The biomarker will incorporate measurements of echogenicity in trigger points, spatial-temporal tissue deformation quantified by strain tensors, and viscoelastic properties of fascia and muscles obtained through ultrasound. The R61 Phase (years 1 to 3) will use deep learning algorithms to integrate these measurements into a predictive biomarker and establish its ability to predict myofascial pain by employing validation methods. The study enrolls participants with no chronic pain (healthy normals), myofascial pain without trigger points, myofascial pain with latent trigger points, and myofascial pain with active trigger points. The primary outcome measure is the diagnosis of one of these MP-related categories determined by standardized clinical examinations, while the secondary outcome measure is the presence of substantial MP based on the same examinations. Keywords related to the study include ultrasound, trigger points, lumbar myofascial pain, thoracolumbar fascia, multifidus muscle, and neural understanding network.

<|assistant|>
The Pain Intervention Via Video Optimization Trial is a two-arm, randomized controlled study examining the effect of a telehealth video intervention on pain recovery and opioid use in opioid-naïve adults with acute musculoskeletal pain presenting at emergency departments or urgent care clinics. Patients are assigned to one of two treatment arms: those receiving the video intervention (which includes an interactive pain management video with multiple-choice questions and a follow-up assessment) or those receiving standard care provided by medical personnel. The study's primary outcome measure is the combined pain severity and interference scores, as reported on the Brief Pain Inventory-short form (BPI-SF) at baseline, 1 month, and 3 months post-visit. Secondary outcome measures include pain severity, pain interference, opioid use, physical function, global health, and healthcare utilization for pain. Eligibility criteria include patients aged 18 or older with acute musculoskeletal pain and a baseline pain score of 4 or higher. The study encompasses 200 patients over the course of 2 years, with stratified randomization based on age. The trial aims to estimate the effectiveness of the telehealth video intervention on pain recovery and opioid use at 3 months.

<|assistant|>
The clinical trial titled "Impact of Neuro-linguistic Programming on Schoolchildren's Performance" aims to evaluate the effectiveness of Neuro-linguistic Programming (NLP) techniques on the academic performance of primary school students in Lebanon between the ages of 5 and 11. The trial involves a single group assignment, where teachers and children undergo 4 and 2 NLP sessions, respectively, developed by a clinical psychologist, a social worker, and an education specialist. The study measures the identification of school triggers, schoolchildren's strengths and difficulties using the Strengths and Difficulties Questionnaire, and concentration, hyperactivity, and reasoning using the Vanderbilt Assessment Scale, all assessed two months after the intervention. The study includes children with Academic Skill Disorder and symptoms of Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) and accepts healthy volunteers. The trial's primary purpose is for supportive care, and its design is single group assignment, with triple masking. The trial aims to assess the impact of NLP techniques on schoolchildren's academic performance, triggers, and ADHD symptoms.

<|assistant|>
This clinical trial, titled "Effect of Using the ECOX Teaching Tool in the Emergency Department on OSCEs for Medical Students: Randomized Controlled Trial," compares the effectiveness of the ECOX tool in improving final grades on service ECOS exams for medical students during their training course to traditional learning methods. The study involves medical students in non-ERASMUS emergency departments who are at least 18 years old and scheduled to participate in service ECOS exams at the end of their internship. The control group will use their usual revision methods, while the interventional group will practice with the ECOX tool available in the emergency department before taking the on-duty OSCEs. The study's primary outcome is the students' average score on end-of-course OSCEs, while secondary outcomes include measures of psychological status and behavioral assessment during service ECOS exams. The study duration is 10 weeks.

<|assistant|>
The study aims to investigate the effects of a web-based health care program on symptom management, social support, activity tolerance, and quality of life in pulmonary hypertension patients aged 20-90 with clear consciousness, normal hearing, and no mental illness or substance abuse. Eligible participants have Group1 or Group4 pulmonary hypertension diagnoses and internet/mobile internet access. The study has two arms: an experimental group receives the web-based program, and a control group receives standard care. The program aims to improve social support, self-care ability, active tolerance, symptom distress, depression, and anxiety in pulmonary hypertension patients. The study measures symptom interference, social support, activity ability, and quality of life using standardized scales at six months compared to baseline. The study is a randomized, parallel-group, double-blind design. The study's primary outcome is a reduction in symptom interference, and its secondary outcomes include improvements in social support, activity ability, and quality of life.

<|assistant|>
The study, titled "Effects of Long Term Ventilation Support on the Quality of Life of ALS Patients and Their Families," aims to measure the overall quality of life, health-related quality of life, and disease-specific quality of life of ALS patients who choose long term mechanical ventilation support (Active Comparator: ALS patients that choose life prolonging treatment with LTMV) and their families, as well as ALS patients who decline this treatment (Active Comparator: ALS patients that decline life prolonging treatment with LTMV) and their families. The study will use two questionnaires, the Quality of Life Scale (range 16-112, higher score indicates better quality of life) and Severe Respiratory Insufficiency Questionnaire (range 0-100, 100 reflects the best health state), to assess overall and health-related quality of life, respectively, at various time points (baseline, 3 months, 9 months, 15 months, and 21 months) for both ALS patients and their families. The study will also employ the Kidsscreen-27 (mean score of 50 ± 10) and Zarit Burden Interview (range 0-88, higher score indicates greater burden) to assess health-related quality of life and caregiver burden for children or adolescents aged 8-18 years and their primary caregivers, respectively, at the same time points. The Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis assessment scale - 5 items (ALSAQ-5) (range 0-100, lower score indicates better health state) will be used to evaluate disease-specific quality of life at baseline, 3 months, 9 months, 15 months, and 21 months for both ALS patients and their families.

In summary, this study aims to examine the impact of long term mechanical ventilation support on the quality of life of ALS patients and their families, as well as on their caregivers, using multiple assessment tools at various time points.

Can you provide me with a summary of the clinical trial "A Rapid Diagnostic of Risk in Hospitalized Patients Using Machine Learning"?
Generate according to: Study Overview
=================

Detailed Description
-----------------
The objective of this proposal is to rapidly deploy a clinical decision support tool (eCARTv5) within the electronic health record of multiple medical-surgical units. eCART combines a real-time machine learning algorithm for identifying patients at increased risk for intensive care (ICU) transfer and death with clinical pathways to standardize the care of these patients based on a real-time, quantitative assessment of patient risk. The investigators hypothesize that implementing such a tool will be associated with a decrease in ventilator utilization, length of stay, and mortality for high-risk hospitalized adults. Background: Clinical deterioration occurs in approximately 5% of hospitalized adults. Delays in recognition of deterioration heighten the risk of adverse outcomes. Machine learning algorithms enhance clinical decision-making and can improve the quality of patient care. However, their impact on clinical outcomes depends not only on the sensitivity and specificity of the algorithm but also on how well that algorithm is integrated into provider workflows and facilitates timely and appropriate intervention. Preliminary Data: eCART has been built upon more than a decade of ongoing scientific research and chronicled in numerous peer-reviewed publications. eCART was developed at the University of Chicago by Drs. Dana Edelson and Matthew Churpek. The first version (eCARTv1) was derived and validated using linear logistic regression in a dataset of nearly 60,000 adult ward patients from a single medical center. That model had 16 variables in it and was subsequently validated in silent mode, demonstrating that eCART could alert clinicians more than 24 hours in advance of ICU transfer or cardiac arrest. eCARTv2, derived and validated in a dataset of nearly 270,000 patients from 5 hospitals, improved upon the earlier version by utilizing a cubic spline logistic regression model with 27 variables and demonstrated improved accuracy over the Modified Early Warning Score (MEWS), a commonly used score that can be hand- calculated by nurses at the bedside (AUC 0.77 vs. 0.70 for cardiac arrest, ICU transfer or death). In a multicenter clinical implementation study, eCARTv2 was associated with a 29% relative risk reduction for mortality. In further development of eCART, the University of Chicago research team demonstrated that upgrading from a cubic spline model to a machine learning model, such as a random forest or gradient boosted machine (GBM), could increase the AUC. In the most recent development - eCART v5 - the research team has advanced the analytic using a gradient boosted machine learning model trained on a multi-center dataset of more than 800,000 patient records. Now with 97 variables, this more sophisticated model increases the accuracy by which clinicians can predict clinical deterioration.

Official Title
-----------------
A Rapid Diagnostic of Risk in Hospitalized Patients With COVID-19, Sepsis, and Other High-Risk Conditions to Improve Outcomes and Critical Resource Allocation Using Machine Learning

This clinical trial, titled "Evaluation of a Proactive Identification and Digital Mental Health Intervention Approach to Address Unmet Psychosocial Needs of Individuals Living With Cancer," is designed to compare the effectiveness of a behavioral activation therapy app called Moodivate and traditional treatment as usual for managing depression among cancer survivors with elevated symptoms. Participants in both arms will have weekly questionnaire measures for 4 weeks following study enrollment, with participants in the Moodivate group also asked to utilize the app daily for 8 weeks and provide additional questionnaire responses at 12 weeks. The primary outcome measure is accrual, the proportion of eligible participants who enroll in the study. Eligibility criteria include elevated depressive symptoms, Smartphone ownership, regular email or text message access, English fluency, and no severe cognitive impairment or current suicidal ideation on the PHQ-9 at screening or final study eligibility. The study, titled "Pilot Study for the Evaluation of Algorithms for the Detection of Subcutaneous Insulin Pump Malfunctions in Subjects With Type 1 Diabetes," aims to test new algorithms for detecting pump and infusion set malfunctions that result in reduced or interrupted insulin delivery in individuals with Type 1 diabetes using automated insulin delivery (AID) systems, also known as artificial pancreas. The study consists of three phases: Phase 1 involves collecting free-living data related to glycemic trends and insulin administration to enable the algorithms to learn how insulin and meals impact the patient's glucose levels. Phase 2 involves inducing hyperglycemia during a clinic visit by temporarily suspending insulin infusion to simulate a pump malfunction, which is closely monitored under medical supervision. Phase 3 involves a retrospective analysis of the collected data to evaluate the effectiveness of the proposed algorithms in detecting pump malfunctions. The study's primary outcome measure is sensitivity, which is defined as the fraction of correctly detected insulin suspensions in the population, during the intervention, when insulin infusion is temporarily suspended to simulate a pump fault. The uniqueness of this dataset lies in the controlled induction of malfunction, achieved by disconnecting the insulin pump and monitoring the resulting hyperglycemic episode. The study's eligibility criteria include individuals aged 18 to 70 years with Type 1 diabetes, treated with AID for at least three months, using carbohydrate counting to calculate meal bolus, and experiencing mild hypothyroidism or high cholesterol. The study's primary purpose is supportive care, and the intervention involves simulating an insulin pump failure by suspending insulin infusion during the inpatient simulation of pump malfunctions to monitor the resulting hyperglycemia. The secondary outcome measure is false positive per day, which is the number of false alarms normalized by the number of days of monitoring during the outpatient data collection.

The study aims to introduce a new technique called the coconut technique for performing safe cholecystectomy on patients with stage II acute cholecystitis as outlined by the Tokyo guidelines, within three days of symptom onset. The technique involves cutting 3-4 cm of the inflamed gallbladder wall with electrocautery, followed by making an incision in a safe zone at the junction of the infundibulum and body of the gallbladder. The separation between the outer layer and inner layer is then searched for to identify the confluence between the cystic duct and the gallbladder body. The cystic duct is then clipped, allowing for lifting and turning over of the gallbladder, leaving the common bile duct (CBD) untouched. This technique allows for a subtotal cholecystectomy with safe identification of the cystic duct. The study will be measuring the effectiveness of this technique over a period of two years. Key terms related to the study include acute cholecystitis, cholecystectomy, and cystic duct.

Can you provide a brief overview of the ICEBERG trial and the rationale behind choosing to measure C-reactive protein as a biomarker in relation to cardiovascular events?
Generate according to: Rationale: The concept that chronic inflammation is intimately linked with the pathogenesis of atherosclerosis is not new and there is accumulating data that inflammatory markers are associated with future cardiovascular events in apparently stable patients after MI.1 C-reactive protein (CRP) is a marker of inflammation which is easily measured in the clinical setting. However there are no data available on its potential prognostic value and possible role in guiding pharmacological therapy after MI. These points form the rationale behind choosing to measure CRP as a biomarker in relation to cardiovascular events and possible roles for treatment strategies.
Glycoprotein IIb/IIIa inhibitors, such as clopidogrel and ticlopidine are commonly used in cardiology and haematology. In the case of clopidogrel, a large body of evidence demonstrates that it is an effective anti-platelet drug. However the extent of benefit conferred by this drug is uncertain and there is considerable inter-individual variation in response which results in excess bleeding in some cases. This study aims to increase our understanding of the mechanisms that are responsible for these phenomena.
Aim: The ICEBERG study aims to recruit 10,500 patients with a recent acute coronary syndrom (ACS) or who have had a coronary intervention. All patients will be randomised to either standard of care, i.e. Clopidogrel 75mg daily, or an intensive strategy, i.e. Twice daily dosing, for 9 months. The effect of this strategy will be monitored with regard to cardiovascular events, bleeding events and mortality. This will be done in order to determine whether or not intensification of anti-platelet therapy may be an effective strategy in order to optimise the net clinical benefit, or whether or not such an approach may in fact lead to excess bleeding which would result in net harm, i.e. Confer additional fatal and non-fatal bleeding events relative to the cardiovascular benefits conferred. Measures will also be undertaken with regard to CRP levels in order to determine whether or not such patients have elevated levels of CRP, and whether or not this is associated with excess cardiovascular events.

Official Title
-----------------
Effect of Intensive Anti-Platelet Therapy on Cardiovascular Events and Bleeding Following Coronary Intervention or Presentation With Acute Coronary Syndromes (ICEBERG): A Multicentre, Prospective, Randomised Controlled Trial

Conditions
-----------------
Cardiovascular Diseases

Participation Criteria
===============
Eligibility Criteria
-----------------
Inclusion Criteria:
1. Patients with a recent ACS (defined as the presence or absence of ST segment elevation, T wave inversion and/or dynamic changes in cardiac biomarkers associated with ischaemia of the heart) presenting to a relevant institution within 24 hours prior to randomisation, or
2. Patients undergoing a coronary intervention (PCI) with documented evidence of significant coronary artery lesions (≥50% diameter stenosis) regardless of the presence or absence of ST segment elevation, T wave inversion and/or dynamic changes in cardiac biomarkers associated with ischaemia of the heart.
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Allergic reaction to clopidogrel or ticlopidine, and
2. Lif-threatening bleeding in the 30 days prior to presentation (defined as transfusion of ≥4 units of blood products or a fall in haematocrit of ≥15%), and
3. High risk surgical procedure (defined as a surgical procedure other than a PCI, coronary artery bypass grafting or carotid endarterectomy) within 7 days prior to presentation, and
4. Other conditions deemed by the Investigator to make the patient unsuitable for entry into the Trial.

Ages Eligible for Study
-----------------
Minimum Age: 18 Years

Sexes Eligible for Study
-----------------------
All

Study Plan
==================

How is the study designed?
-----------------

This clinical trial compares the effects of intrathecal bupivacaine combined with dexmedetomidine and neostigmine in elective cesarean deliveries. Eligible patients are ASA physical status I and II with ages between 18-40 years, height between 150-170 cm, and weight between 70-110 kg who are not pregnant or lactating, do not have cardiac or neurological disorders, and do not have allergy to local anesthetics or neostigmine. The primary outcomes will be measuring the sensitivity and specificity of BileCAD analysis in patients with BTC and non-cancer patients, while the secondary outcomes will include an analysis of the consistency between BileCAD's microbial analysis results and clinical microbial culture results, and the sensitivity of BileCAD to different types and sites of malignant tumors.

This clinical trial aims to develop a novel biomarker, virus-host chimera DNA (vh-DNA), for responding and predicting prognosis in patients with hepatitis B virus (HBV)-related hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) undergoing radiotherapy (RT). The study will use previously collected samples from patients who underwent RT and will analyze the consistency of junctional clones by Capture NGS and changes in vh-DNA copies by ddPCR in representative cases. The study will also identify HBV integrations by Capture NGS and quantify vh-DNA by ddPCR as a personalized biomarker. The study will prospectively collect plasma samples from patients before, after, and after RT at specific intervals and will correlate changes in vh-DNA copy numbers with clinical response and recurrence/metastasis. The study aims to reveal the true value of this novel biomarker for earlier evaluating RT response, disease monitoring, and distinguishing clonality at recurrence in future clinical trials on combination therapies. The clinical trial titled "Guided Versus Standard Antiplatelet Therapy in Intracranial Aneurysm Intervention With Stents: a Cluster Randomized Controlled Cohort Study" is aimed at comparing the effectiveness of a guided antiplatelet regimen based on LTA testing with the standard dual antiplatelet therapy in patients with unruptured intracranial aneurysms undergoing intracranial stenting. Eligible participants must be aged between 18 to 80, have a Modified Rankin Scale score lower than 2, and agree to sign the consent form. The primary outcome measurement is the occurrence of ischemic events within 30 days after stent implantation, including ischemic stroke, transient ischemic attacks (TIA), and stent thrombosis. The guided antiplatelet regimen involves adjusting the antiplatelet drugs based on the results of LTA tests performed at least 1 day before stent implantation. The control group will continue to receive the center's original antiplatelet regimen, which consists of oral aspirin 100mg and clopidogrel 75mg daily. The study design is a cluster randomized controlled cohort study, and the allocation is randomized with a parallel assignment, and masking is single. The conditions being studied are intracranial aneurysms, and the intervention is the use of the guided antiplatelet regimen based on LTA testing. Key terms associated with this study include intracranial aneurysm, interventional therapy, stent, platelet, ischemic stroke, and bleeding event.

The HYGEF study, which translates to "Hypertension in High School Students: Genetic and Environmental Factors," aims to determine the prevalence of hypertension and obesity in a cohort of Italian adolescents from three regions of the country. Additionally, the study will explore the connection between urine sodium and potassium excretion, as well as markers of inflammation and oxidative stress, with hypertension and cardiovascular risk in participants with selected genotypes. The study enrolls adolescents aged 13 to 19 years from high schools in northern, central, and southern Italy to obtain a representative sample. During their visit, participants provide questionnaires regarding dietary habits, lifestyle, and family history, as well as blood pressure readings, height, weight, urine and saliva samples. Genotyping is performed for 15 selected SNPs in 13 candidate genes, and urinary analyses are conducted to measure various substances such as IL1β, IL6, and nitric oxide, as well as advanced oxidation protein products. The study has a duration of two years, and terms related to hypertension, adolescence, obesity, and genetics are relevant keywords. The primary outcome is establishing a link between specific genetic polymorphisms and phenotypes, including hypertension, sodium and potassium intake.

During HD, microbubbles will be counted using an ultrasound device, and comparative non-parametric paired analyses will be performed between the air traps. The study's primary outcome measure is the reduction in air microemboli contamination, and comparison of contamination between hemodialysis and hemodiafiltration is a secondary outcome. Adverse events will also be reported.

The study aims to evaluate the accuracy of pocket-sized ultrasound (PsUS) in diagnosing pediatric elbow fractures compared to radiography, as performed by pediatric emergency medicine physicians. The feasibility study, involving three elbow exams for novice PsUS users, will test the ability to obtain accurate and adequate images for interpretation. The active study will recruit children with isolated acute elbow pain, where patients will undergo standardized elbow exams using PsUS, with images stored on a cloud-based imaging database. After obtaining initial test performance characteristics of PsUS compared to radiography, researchers will follow up with participants after their ED visit to determine if any additional fractures were discovered on later imaging. The study will exclude children under one year or over sixteen years old, as well as those with open fractures, multiple traumatic injuries, unstable vital signs, altered mental status, or past elbow fracture. The study will primarily measure the accuracy of PsUS elbow exams, with sensitivity, specificity, negative and positive predictive values compared to X-ray or bedside nursemaid reduction as the gold standard. The feasibility of the PsUS study training and protocol for image capture will also be assessed during the internal review of images. Keywords for this study include pocket-sized ultrasound, pediatric elbow injury, and pediatric elbow fracture.

This clinical trial, titled "Imaging Characterization of the Biomechanical Coupling of Brain and Skull," aims to study the biomechanical relationship between the brain and skull in three groups of participants: those with a history of mild traumatic brain injury (TBI) and no traumatic meningeal enhancement (TME), those with a history of mild TBI and TME, and healthy controls. The study will use magnetic resonance elastography (MRE) to measure the relative motion of the brain and skull while the head is vibrated at specific frequencies. The primary outcome measure is the estimation of global differences in the amplitudes and temporal delays of translation and rotation between brain and skull, with lower temporal delays indicating tighter coupling. Local measures of skull-brain coupling will also be measured using octahedral shear strain, with higher strains representing higher deformation. The study aims to enroll a total of 110 participants, with 75 having a history of TBI and 35 being healthy controls. The study endpoints are the completion of the MRE visit for each participant, and the data will be used to characterize the biomechanical coupling of the skull-brain interface in each group. The study is open to participants without clinical TBI, but excludes those with inner ear problems causing dizziness and other known conditions affecting brain anatomy.

The secondary outcome measure will be the occurrence of cardiovascular clinical complexes, including cardiovascular death, non-fatal myocardial infarction, coronary artery reopening, or ischemic stroke, within 6 months after randomization. Can you provide a brief summary of the key findings or results from the OPTI-DOSE trial mentioned in the text? Answer according to: OPTI - DOSE: Optimal Dosing of Oral Anticancer Drugs in Older Adults

Study Overview
=================

Detailed Description
-----------------
Information about the benefits and side effects of treatments for cancer is mainly derived from studies with younger patients. It is known that elderly patients experience more side effects from treatments, which can lead to a worse quality of life. The study hypothesis is that a lower starting dose of anticancer tablet treatments can lead to better treatment tolerability in older patients, while the benefits of treatment can be the same. The trial population consists of 30 patients aged 65 years or older, who are starting treatment with one of these anti cancer tablet treatments: pazopanib, olaparib, lenvatinib, sunitinib or palbociclib. This is a randomized study with 1:1 randomisation, stratified by type of anti-cancer treatment. The control group (half of the participants) will be treated with the standard-of-care, that means with the recommended starting dose of the anti cancer tablets as described in the drug label. The dose can be adjusted (lowered) if this is necessary, for example because of side effects, based on the judgment of the treating physician. The interventional group (half of the participants) will start with the lowest dose of the anti cancer tablets as described in the drug label. The dose will be increased every two weeks in case of good tolerability. Results of this pilot study will be used to inform the design of the larger randomised phase 2 trial, for example the primary endpoint, the amount of investigations and the size of the study population. Study visits are planned every 2 weeks for a total study duration of 12 weeks, the time point for analysis of the primary endpoint. Blood samples for PK analysis are collected every 2 weeks. A baseline blood sample will be collected for pharmacogenomic analysis.

Official Title

Optimal Dosing of Oral Anticancer Drugs in Older Adults With Cancer: a Randomized Pilot Study.

The ASCERTAIN study is a phase IV, randomized, open-label trial aimed at evaluating the implementation and utility of a new model of care for individuals with atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) or ASCVD-risk equivalents who have elevated levels of low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C). The study will enroll approximately 600 participants at 20 sites in Australia, with half receiving the new model of care and half receiving usual care. The new model of care includes monthly text messages about cardiovascular health and appointment reminders, as well as telephone-based support calls with a study nurse trained in motivational interviewing. Both arms will receive maximally tolerated statin and/or ezetimibe therapy with or without other LDL-C lowering therapies as per the treating physician's discretion. The study's primary outcome is the change in LDL-C concentration at day 180, while the secondary outcome is the change in LDL-C concentration at day 365. The study's main objectives are to assess the effectiveness of the new model of care in achieving clinical guidelines for LDL-C management, improve medication adherence, and address gaps in lipid testing and access to full management tools. The study will also investigate the feasibility of implementing this new model of care in primary care settings. The study is a multi-site project that will be conducted in four community health centers throughout Pennsylvania serving populations of primarily African American and Latino women. Alcohol and other drug use are known to compound risks associated with unintended pregnancies, subfertility, and sexually transmitted infections (STIs), and their consequences for maternal and child health. Current guidelines recommend that all adults seeking health care services receive screening and brief interventions for these issues. However, less than 5% of family planning settings currently provide screening and brief intervention services for alcohol and drugs.

This study will establish and evaluate the implementation of comprehensive alcohol and substance use screening and brief interventions for women and men in family planning settings, and will determine an empirically derived strategy for sustainment. To achieve this, the project draws on both effectiveness and implementation science, with a study design consistent with the Type III Effectiveness-Implementation Hybrid Design, which aims to develop and test contextualized models that integrate evidence-based practices in real world settings, and to determine which implementation strategies are best suited to support and maintain adoption of those practices. The project combines (1) a rigorous effectiveness study, which involves a 1:1:1 dextrally randomized cluster design with 36 clinics in a 12-month period to compare usual care (UC) to enhanced usual care (EUC: SBIRT) to SBIRT delivered by telehealth through the TFI System, and (2) an implementation science study which employs a mixed-methods approach to determine (a) the barriers and facilitators to implementing SBIRT, (b) the impact of those barriers and facilitators on provider behavior and the utilization of SBIRT clinical services, and (c) how they may be overcome or exploited in practice settings, and (d) in a secondary analysis to compare outcomes among women within EUC clinics versus those in TFI clinics.

A secondary analysis will take place to determine whether implementing SBIRT through telehealth (TFI) results in increased utilization of alcohol and substance use screening, brief intervention and referral services for (i) contraceptive methods, (ii) sexually transmitted infection (STI) testing and treatment, and (iii) women's health, (iv) patient satisfaction, and (v) health care costs, and whether these effects are sustained over time. The project will utilize an implementation-effectiveness hybrid design that employs the framework that considers the interaction between contextual factors and implementation processes on the one hand, and the outcomes of interest on the other hand, a framework informed by Consolidated Framework for Implementation Research, the Explanatory Matrix, and the Theoretical Domains Framework.

The protocol also describes an embedded process evaluation study aimed at advancing our understanding of how the barriers and facilitators of implementation to technology-based SBIRT occur at multiple levels (i.e., organizational, practitioner, patient), and how the implementation strategies adopted and adapted to mitigate or leverage those barriers and facilitators (i.e., incentives training, supervision, coaching, consultation, and feedback), how the processes of adaptation, refinement, and tailoring evolve in real-world settings, and how they contribute to, or detract from, the overall implementation outcome, namely the adoption and sustainment of SBIRT.

The study aims to provide insights into the potential use of herbal tea infusions as a means of promoting well-being through lipid modulation and gut health improvement.

The study will have four intervention groups: early intervention (additional training within 60 days of injury), sub-acute intervention (training at 3 months post-injury), chronic intervention (training at 6-12 months post-injury), and no intervention (standard of care). The study aims to understand the significant time window for rehabilitation after SCI and how it could impact recovery outcomes.

Can you provide a brief explanation of hydraulic cavitation cleaning and how it differs from passive ultrasonic irrigation and conventional root canal preparation?

Summary: Hydraulic cavitation cleaning uses high-pressure saline solution to create bubbles which implode violently in the root canal, removing debris and bacteria. In contrast, passive ultrasonic irrigation uses low-frequency vibrations to agitate saline solution and dislodges debris, while conventional root canal preparation involves manual or rotary instrumentation with no irrigation during the procedure.

The FRACT-AI trial aims to evaluate the impact of artificial intelligence (AI) on the diagnostic accuracy of frontline clinicians in the detection of fractures on plain X-rays. The clinical trial, titled "Macrophage PET/CT Imaging for the Diagnosis of Cardiac Sarcoidosis," aims to investigate the use of 64Cu-DOTATATE as a PET/CT tracer for diagnosing cardiac sarcoidosis. Patients with neuroendocrine tumors (group D) who have previously been scanned with 64Cu-DOTATATE will also be included as controls. The primary outcome is the proportion of patients with tracer uptake in the heart in cardiac sarcoidosis patients and the lack thereof in neuroendocrine tumor patients. Secondary outcomes include rates of adverse outcomes and the distribution of tracer uptake in cardiac sarcoidosis and acute lymphocytic myocarditis patients. Eligible participants include individuals aged 18 and older with suspected or confirmed cardiac sarcoidosis, suspected or confirmed acute lymphocytic myocarditis, or neuroendocrine tumors. Exclusion criteria include severe obesity, pregnancy, severe claustrophobia, known allergy to 64Cu-DOTATATE, clinically critical conditions that impede PET/CT procedures, and diabetes with insulin dependence. The study duration is two years.

The IRIS program is a treatment approach for injection-related infections in individuals who inject drugs in Hamilton, Ontario. The study aims to optimize treatment for injection-related infections through a one-stop, low-barrier combined care model that includes diagnosis, substance use treatment, peer support, and care coordination/systems navigation. The primary outcome measure is the number of emergency department visits and hospital readmissions within 30 days of initial hospital admission or program enrolment. Secondary outcome measures include completion of intended treatment, number of hospital readmissions and emergency department visits related to the primary infection, number of new initiation or continuation of substance use treatment, mortality rates, and program drop-out rates and reasons. The study only includes participants aged 16 or older with a confirmed or suspected injection-related infection who have injected in the past three months and reside in Hamilton. The study is a single group assignment with no masking. Holistic injection-related injection treatment is provided to intervention group participants, which includes additional supports to address social and medical needs based on individual needs.

This clinical study is titled "A Study to Evaluate the Safety, Tolerability, Pharmacokinetics, and Pharmacodynamics of Pozelimab Following Subcutaneous Administration in Adult Participants With Primary Hypergalactosemia or Congenital Hypergalactosemia" and is being conducted by Roche. The primary objectives of this study are to assess the safety, tolerability, pharmacokinetics (PK), and pharmacodynamics (PD) of subcutaneous (SC) administration of pozelimab in adult participants with primary hypergalactosemia or congenital hypergalactosemia. Specifically, the study aims to evaluate the incidence, frequency, and types of treatment-emergent adverse events (TEAEs), serious adverse events (SAEs), and TEAEs leading to permanent discontinuation of pozelimab. It will also measure PK parameters, including the maximum observed plasma concentration (Cmax), time to reach Cmax (Tmax), area under the concentration-time curve from time zero to the last measurable concentration (AUC0-t), and area under the concentration-time curve extrapolated to infinity (AUC0-inf). In addition, the PD effects on markers of hepatic gluconeogenesis and galactose metabolism will be evaluated. The study is expected to recruit a total of 40 participants with a diagnosis of primary hypergalactosemia or congenital hypergalactosemia, and it will be conducted in multiple study centers over a period of approximately 48 weeks.

Cognitive stimulation therapy is a widely recommended and evidence-based intervention for individuals with mild to moderate dementia, with significant effects on cognitive, psychological, and social aspects. This study will contribute to clinical practice by standardizing CST and assessing its effects, as its application by nurses is limited in Turkey. No pharmacological interventions are being tested in this study, given the limitations of pharmacological methods for AD patients in Turkey.

The study participants are adults undergoing scheduled surgeries at Lariboisière Hospital, and there is no requirement for healthy volunteers. Vital signs, including mean arterial pressure, are continuously monitored, and cerebral blood velocity, burst suppression, and 95% spectral frequency front are also monitored using Transcranial Pulsed Doppler (TCD) and electroencephalography. Cerebral oxygen saturation is measured using near-infrared spectroscopy. Data is collected and analyzed using an intraoperative data extraction system, which captures digital tracings and measurements at a fine sampling rate. The primary objective is to identify a significant linear relationship between the percentage change in mean velocity and percentage change in 95% spectral frequency front during blood pressure changes to evaluate cerebrovascular autoregulation. Secondary objectives include analysis of this relationship in relation to EEG markers, such as alpha band power, time spent in burst-suppression, and delta-to-alpha ratio. The study plan involves monitoring blood velocity during the adjustment of mean arterial pressure levels between 90% and 70% of the baseline value, while ensuring that it does not go below 60 mmHg for patients at low risk and 80 mmHg for patients at high cardiovascular risk. The trial intends to reject the null hypothesis based on the R2 measure of goodness of fit, with a sample size of 100 participants to compensate for potential confounding factors and adjustments due to cerebrovascular autoregulation impairment. The study does not involve additional interventions, and no participant will experience prolonged anesthetic procedures due to the intraoperative EEG monitoring, which is a standard practice in this type of surgery.

The PROSPECT study is a prospective, observational investigation collecting data on complications and outcomes following pleural interventions in patients. It will enroll at least 20 centers, and all patients undergoing pleural procedures, such as thoracocentesis or pleural biopsies, will participate. Complications will be objectively defined, and baseline procedure information will be recorded. Centers will report details according to specified criteria, with some specifying the level of detail they provide. Patients will complete measures of chest pain and breathlessness pre- and post-procedure, as well as a questionnaire if undergoing indwelling catheter or chest drain insertion. The study will include a mix of district general and tertiary referral centers and aims to provide a best-practice standard against which smaller-volume centers can benchmark to ensure patient safety. The primary outcome measure is complications, including bleeding, infection, pneumothorax, organ injury, pain, and re-expansion pulmonary edema, within 30 days. Secondary measures include patient-reported outcomes of dyspnea and chest pain within 4 weeks. Terms related to the study include pleural diseases, mesothelioma, pneumothorax, pleural effusion, infection, neoplasms, metastases, procedural complications, and combinations.

The study, titled "Artificial Intelligence for Preventing Heart Disease: Observational, Single Center, Prospective and Retrospective Study," aims to develop an AI-based model for risk stratification of coronary artery disease (CAD) patients. The study will involve a retrospective cohort of 2500 patients and a prospective cohort of 500 patients undergoing clinically indicated coronary computed tomography angiography (cCTA) for CAD evaluation. The primary outcome measure will be a composite outcome of death by cardiovascular events or non-fatal myocardial infarction, measured 36 months from the CCTA examination. Additionally, a secondary outcome measure will assess all-cause mortality, non-fatal myocardial infarction, hospitalization due to angina or angina-like symptoms, and late coronary revascularization. The study seeks to address the lack of integration of AI-based applications in the clinical workflow and will develop a platform for external validation of the algorithm. The study aims to overcome current issues hampering the widespread clinical application of AI in cardiovascular care, including the integration of AI-based applications into the clinical workflow, interoperability with current clinical software, and user-friendliness. The study will analyze multiple prognosticator imaging and clinical parameters, including coronary artery vessel wall characteristics, pericoronary adipose tissue attenuation, coronary artery topology, and AI-based integration of these parameters. The study will address the lack of studies on the association between coronary artery topology and prognosis. The proposed AI-based model is expected to identify and categorize patients at high risk of disease progression and offer a more personalized management approach to improve patient outcomes.

Terms:

- Clinical trial: a research study performed in people that are aimed at evaluating a medical, surgical, or behavioral intervention.
- Conditions: the specific health problems or disorders being studied.
- Intervention or treatment: the medical, surgical, or behavioral intervention being studied, in this case, pyrotinib.
- Participation criteria: the requirements participants must meet to be eligible for the clinical trial.
- Ages eligible for study: the age range for which participants may be enrolled in the trial.
- Sexes eligible for study: the gender(s) eligible to participate in the trial.
- Accepts healthy volunteers: whether healthy individuals may participate in the trial.
- Study plan: the design details of the trial, such as primary and secondary outcomes, intervention, and study duration.
- Primary outcome measures: the specific outcomes being evaluated as the trial's primary focus.
- Secondary outcome measures: additional outcomes being evaluated as part of the trial but not as its primary focus.
- Adverse events (AEs): unfavorable or adverse reactions to a medication or intervention.
- Serious adverse events (SAEs): adverse events that result in death, are life-threatening, require hospitalization, or significantly impair daily activity.
- CACTE: an acronym for Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events, a uniform standard for reporting adverse events.
- Summary: a brief, clear, and accurate description of the trial's key aspects.

This clinical trial, titled "The Role of Oxidative Stress and Mitochondrial TERT in the Progression and Therapeutic Resistance of Papillary Thyroid Cancer," aims to investigate the levels of oxidative stress and mitochondrial TERT (an enzyme important for telomere maintenance) in papillary thyroid cancer (PTC) and normal tissues. Primary outcomes include measuring H2O2 generation and TERT mitochondrial localization in PTC and normal tissues, as well as examining the effect of oxidative stress and therapeutic agents on TERT translocation in thyroid cancer cell lines. Secondary outcomes include genetic characterization and expression profiling of tumor tissues. The study excludes patients with inadequate tissue for analysis and those who cannot provide consent or are lost at follow-up. The study design includes measuring these outcomes at specific time points for each experimental procedure.

The study, titled "The Diagnostic and Prognostic Role of SAA in Intrathoracic Sarcoidosis," aims to examine the significance of Serum Amyloid A (SAA) in sarcoidosis patients with intrathoracic involvement. Participants in the intrathoracic sarcoidosis cohort (aged 18 and above, recently diagnosed with intrathoracic sarcoidosis) will not receive any intervention, while healthy control participants are excluded. The study measures several outcomes, including the correlation of mean SAA concentrations in the sarcoidosis cohort with mean values in healthy controls, the correlation of SAA concentrations at diagnosis with biomarkers for granulomatous inflammation, pulmonary function tests, and radiologic extent of disease, as well as changes in these measures over 3 years of follow-up. The study will also assess the correlation of SAA concentrations at diagnosis with the need for recent/ongoing therapy after 3 years of follow-up. Exclusion criteria include patients with confounding systemic inflammatory illnesses, active cancer, or immunosuppressive therapy.
