The clinical trial titled "Benefit of Early Intrauterine Transfer of Blank Culture Medium Prior to Transfer of a Thawed Embryo From 1st in Vitro Fertilization - Randomized, Single-blind, Multicenter Controlled Trial" aims to investigate the effectiveness of transferring blank culture medium into the uterus before the transfer of a thawed embryo in women who have undergone a first fresh or frozen embryo transfer resulting in pregnancy failure while having at least two eligible embryos. The study involves two interventions: a blank culture transfer and a sham transfer, both within a randomized, single-blind, multicenter design. The primary outcome measure is the clinically progressive pregnancy rate between groups as measured by ultrasound at 12 weeks of amenorrhea. Secondary outcome measures include the occurrence of pregnancy, biochemical pregnancy, clinical pregnancy, early miscarriage, and live birth, as well as the differential cost-result ratio and total estimated expenditure for the two care strategies compared over a one-year time horizon. The study is limited to women meeting the inclusion criteria, up to the age of 39, and excludes participants who are participating in another study or under safeguard or state guardianship.

The clinical trial aims to develop a database by gathering information through questionnaires and medical records from solid tumor patients receiving immunotherapy for the first time. The study will analyze factors affecting the effectiveness and prognosis of immunotherapy, including demographic data, tumor and anti-tumor history, gene testing results, and adverse reaction prevention strategies. The primary outcome measure is disease-free progression survival (PFS) over two years, with secondary outcomes of overall survival and quality of life scores. The trial is a multicenter, observational, and controlled cohort study seeking high-level evidence-based medical evidence for precision immunotherapy selection, prevention of adverse reactions, and improved survival.

The clinical trial titled "Confidential Social Network Referrals for HIV Testing" aims to investigate the effectiveness of two referral methods, CONSORT referrals and card referrals, in increasing HIV testing among social and sexual network contacts in Moshi, Tanzania. Participants aged 18 and above who are literate and reside, work, or frequently seek care in the area are eligible. They will be randomly assigned to one of two arms: the experimental arm receives both CONSORT and card referrals, while the control arm only receives card referrals. The primary outcome measure is the number of referred individuals presenting for HIV testing within 30 days of being offered a test, expressed as tests per 100 index clients. The study design is parallel assignment, and neither masking nor placebo is used. The study's primary objective is health services research, and only behavioral interventions are administered.

The clinical trial, titled "Effects of Paroxetine on Cardiovascular Function in Septic Patients: a Randomized Placebo Controlled Trial," aims to investigate the impact of paroxetine on cardiovascular function in patients with septic shock. Eligible participants are individuals aged 18 or older who have been diagnosed with septic shock for less than 48 hours and are currently using a minimum dose of noradrenaline. The study has two arms: a placebo comparator group and an experimental group that receives paroxetine in a dosage of 40mg per day for five consecutive days or until shock resolution. The primary outcome measure is time to vasopressor discontinuation within 28 days of enrollment, and secondary measures include cumulative vasopressor dose, cardiovascular sequential organ failure assessment score, and length of ICU stay and mortality rate during the ICU stay. The study is randomized, quadruple-masked, and has a sample size that may be adjusted based on committee recommendation after analysis of the first 20 patients due to the removal of the fluoxetine comparator group.

The clinical trial, titled "Paramedical Tele-education on Moderate Depressive Episodes," aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a paramedical tele-education program for individuals experiencing moderate depressive episodes in primary care. Participants who meet the inclusion criteria of presenting a moderate depressive episode, antidepressant medication usage within the past two months, and compatible follow-up capacity by their general practitioner will be randomized into either the experimental or control group. The experimental group will receive a five-session tele-education program focused on educational diagnosis, hygienic and dietary measures, symptoms of depression, antidepressant information, and assessment. The control group will receive standard care from their general practitioner, along with an educational booklet on depression. The primary endpoint is medication adherence measured by antidepressant usage three months after the trial. Secondary endpoints include changes in self-efficacy and barriers to treatment as assessed through specifically designed scales. The study's key term is "psychoeducation."

This pilot observational study aims to assess the ability of continuous at-home EEG (recorded using the Dreem Headband) to accurately diagnose Narcolepsy Type 1 and demonstrate response to treatment compared to the standard in-patient clinical testing with polysomnography and multiple sleep latency test (ICSD-3 protocol). It will recruit participants aged 12-25 with excessive daytime sleepiness, who are already under investigation for hypersomnolence at GSTT children and adult sleep service, and excludes those with sleep disorders, medical or psychiatric issues, or regular medication use affecting sleep. The study will evaluate the sensitivity, specificity, positive predictive value, and negative predictive value of the Dreem Headband in predicting a final diagnosis of Narcolepsy Type 1 over a 2-year period. The study will primarily measure the diagnostic accuracy of the Dreem Headband in comparison to the standard ICSD-3 protocol.

This is a Phase 1/2 open-label trial to evaluate the safety, tolerability, and efficacy of a single dose of SAR444836, an AAV-mediated gene therapy for phenylketonuria (PKU), in adults with a confirmed diagnosis of PKU due to PAH deficiency. Eligible participants must be aged 18-65 years, have a significant elevation in plasma phenylalanine (Phe) levels despite restrictive diets, and be able to maintain their current diet. The trial has a dose-escalation and dose-expansion design, with the primary outcome being the incidence of treatment-emergent adverse events (TEAEs) and secondary outcomes evaluating the sustained reduction in Phe levels, changes in dietary protein intake, and viral vector shedding. The trial aims to assess the safety and efficacy of SAR444836 in reducing Phe levels, as currently, dietary restrictions remain the only effective treatment for PKU.

The clinical trial aims to explore the use of a diagnostic test called pCASL (pseudo-continuous arterial spin labeling) as a substitute for FDG-PET (fluorodeoxyglucose positron emission tomography) in patients with mild cognitive impairment (MCI) or subjective cognitive decline (SCD). The study will compare the correlation between brain hypoperfusion, measured by pCASL, and brain hypometabolism, measured by FDG-PET, at baseline and over a two-year follow-up period. The researchers will also investigate differences in brain perfusion patterns based on amyloid and tau status and correlations between brain hypoperfusion and neuropsychological tests, CSF and blood biomarkers. The study includes patients with MCI or SCD, aged 18-80, with a Clinical Dementia Rating scale of 0 or 0.5, and without major neurological or psychiatric comorbidities. The primary outcome measures are the correlation between brain hypoperfusion and brain hypometabolism at baseline and by CSF profile. Secondary outcome measures include differences in brain perfusion patterns according to amyloid and tau status, correlations between brain hypoperfusion and neuropsychological tests, CSF and blood biomarkers, and predictive properties of brain hypoperfusion and brain hypometabolism for conversion to dementia.

The study is an observational safety surveillance trial for VyndaMx® (tafamidis) in adults with transthyretin amyloid cardiomyopathy (ATTR-CM) in India. Eligible participants on tafamidis for wild or hereditary ATTR-CM will be observed for safety outcomes such as adverse events within 6 months of initiation. The primary endpoint is the number of adverse events. The study is single-arm and conducted in multiple centers. Exclusion criteria include hypersensitivity, rare fructose intolerance, and contraindications to tafamidis based on local product label. Keywords for the study include safety surveillance and tafamidis.

The study is a randomized controlled trial evaluating the STERN FIX device as a sternal stabilization system in patients who undergo median sternotomy for procedures requiring it, as well as those with specific risk factors. Patients with allergies or serious bone damage affecting the sternum are excluded. The study compares two interventions: a combination of the STERN FIX device and wires, and standard of care sternal closure with wires. The primary outcome is sternal stability, measured using a clinical assessment scale one month after surgery. Secondary outcomes include safety, device deficiencies, reinterventions, sternal wound infections, dehiscence, sternal closure time, ease of use, surgeon satisfaction, chest pain, blood loss, upper limb functional capacity, quality of life, sternal halves union/malunion, sternal halves alignment, sternum integrity, and closure system integrity, measured at various time points. Keywords include sternal closure, cardiac surgery, and sternotomy.

This clinical trial aims to compare the hematocrit-to-hemoglobin ratio and red blood cell distribution width in patients with polycythemia vera (PV) to those with secondary erythrocytosis as controls. Patients with PV newly diagnosed between September 2014 and November 2022 at Sohag University Hospital's internal medicine department and hematology unit and outpatient clinic are eligible. Secondary erythrocytosis patients will also be recruited from the same hospital's internal medicine and chest departments for comparison. Data will be collected at the time of diagnosis and include history of thrombosis, complete blood picture including Hematocrit, haemoglobin, red blood cell distribution width, serum uric acid, JAK2V617F mutation status by polymerase chain reaction, bone marrow aspiration, and biopsy with reticulin stain. The study is set to run from December 2022 to September 2023. The primary outcomes measured will be the hematocrit-to-hemoglobin ratio and red blood cell distribution width in both groups. PV and secondary erythrocytosis have been defined as inclusion criteria, while those with chronic respiratory failure, congenital heart diseases, polycystic kidney, and other causes will be recruited as controls for comparison with PV patients.

This clinical trial investigates the usefulness of measuring perfusion index (PI) with the Masimo Radical-7 device in determining emergency triage classification for adult patients with dyspnea upon admission to the hospital. Patients with dyspnea who have PI measurements taken at three time points (on admission, first hour, and second hour) are included, excluding those with trauma, vascular diseases, or COVID-19 PCR positivity with PI measurement restriction. The study aims to determine the effect of PI measurement on emergency triage classification for patients with dyspnea through PI measurements at each time point. The study's primary outcome measures are the PI measurements at each time point to assess the triage status of patients with dyspnea. Keywords associated with the study include dyspnea, emergency, perfusion index, and triage. Designed as a single-group assignment, the study does not employ masking.

The SmartMom trial is a health services research study designed to promote healthy behaviors during pregnancy through text messaging. The study includes pregnant participants at 15 weeks gestation or earlier with a singleton pregnancy, who can read and understand English at a grade 8 level and live in Canada (excluding British Columbia). Participants are randomly assigned to either the SmartMom messaging intervention or a control messaging group. The SmartMom program provides three weekly messages with evidence-based information focused on improving knowledge, promoting healthy behaviors, and encouraging physiologic births. The control group receives weekly messages with general pregnancy information. The study measures changes in weight, attendance at prenatal care visits, health knowledge, health literacy, fear of childbirth, depression, anxiety, tobacco, vaping, alcohol, and cannabis use, planned vaginal birth after cesarean, exclusive breastfeeding, and adverse pregnancy outcomes. The study also evaluates the cost-effectiveness of the SmartMom program compared to the control group. Keywords for the study include prenatal education, perinatal outcomes, text messaging, mobile health, mental health, and health behaviors.
